Âú®ÈÄôÂÄãÊ°à‰æã‰∏≠,f()Áπ´ÁµêÁöÑÁí∞Â¢ÉÁâ©‰ª∂,Â∞±ÊòØÁπ´ÁµêÂêçÁ®±fÁöÑÁí∞Â¢É„ÄÇ‰ΩÜ‰∏¶‰∏ç‰∏ÄÂÆöÁ∏ΩÊòØÈÄôÊ®£Ôºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÂú®‰∏ã‰∏ÄÂÄã‰æãÂ≠ê‰∏≠,gË¢´Áπ´ÁµêÂú®Êñ∞Áí∞Â¢ÉÁâ©‰ª∂e‰∏≠„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÂáΩÊï∏g()Áπ´ÁµêÁöÑÊòØglobal environment„ÄÇÈÄô‰πãÈñìÁöÑÂàÜÂà•ÊòØÊàëÂÄëÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊâæÂà∞gÂíågÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊâæÂà∞‰ªñÁöÑËÆäÊï∏„ÄÇ
e <- env()e$g <- function() 1 Namespaces Âú®‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑÂúñÂΩ¢‰∏≠,ÊàëÂÄëÂ∑≤Á∂ìÁü•ÈÅìÂ•ó‰ª∂ÁöÑparentÊúÉÈö®Ëëó‰πãÂâçÂ•ó‰ª∂ËºâÂÖ•ÁöÑÈ†ÜÂ∫è‰∏çÂêåËÄå‰∏çÂêå„ÄÇÈÄôÂ∞±Â∞éËá¥RÁ®ãÂºèË®≠Ë®àËÄÖÂøÖÈ†à‰øùË≠âÂÄãÂà•Â•ó‰ª∂‰∏äÂ¶ÇÊûú‰ΩøÁî®Âà•ÁöÑÂ•ó‰ª∂ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∏ÔºåÂøÖÈ†àÊòØÂéüÂßãÁõÆÁöÑÁöÑÈÇ£‰∏ÄÂÄã„ÄÇnamespaces Â∞±ÊòØÁÇ∫Ê≠§ÁõÆÁöÑËÄåÁî¢Áîü: ÊØèÂÄãÂ•ó‰ª∂ÂøÖÈ†àÁöÑ‰ΩøÁî®ÂøÖÈ†à‰∏ÄËá¥,ËÄå‰∏çÁÆ°‰ΩøÁî®ËÄÖÂ¶Ç‰ΩïËºâÂÖ•Â•ó‰ª∂.
‰ª• sd()ÁÇ∫‰æãÂ≠ê:
sd#> function (x, na.rm = FALSE) #> sqrt(var(if (is.vector(x) || is.factor(x)) x else as.double(x), #> na.rm = na.rm))#> <bytecode: 0x000000001c9a2d28>#> <environment: namespace:stats> sd() ÂøÖÈ†à‰ΩøÁî®ÂáΩÊï∏ var(), Âõ†Ê≠§ÈÄôÂÄãvar()Âà∞Â∫ï‰æÜËá™ global environment,ÈÇÑÊòØÂÖ∂‰ªñÊé•ÂÖ•(attached)ÁöÑÂ•ó‰ª∂ÁöÑÈÄôÁ®ÆÂïèÈ°åÂøÖÈ†àÈÅøÂÖç„ÄÇ R avoids this problem by taking advantage of the function vs. binding environment described above.
ÊØèÂÄãÂ•ó‰ª∂‰∏≠ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∏Âíå‰∏ÄÂ∞çÁí∞Â¢ÉÁâ©‰ª∂ÊúâÈóú:Â•ó‰ª∂Áí∞Â¢É(‰πãÂâçÂ≠∏Âà∞ÁöÑ)ÈÇÑÊúâ namespace Áí∞Â¢ÉÁâ©‰ª∂„ÄÇ
 package environment: ÊòØÂ•ó‰ª∂ÁöÑÂ§ñÈÉ®‰ªãÈù¢ÔºåÈÄôÊòØR‰ΩøÁî®ËÄÖÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÂú®Êé•ÂÖ•ÁöÑÂ•ó‰ª∂‰∏≠Â∞ãÊâæÂáΩÊï∏ÁöÑÂú∞Êñπ(ÊàñËÄÖÂèØ‰ª•Âà©Áî® ::) package enviromnent ÁöÑparent Áî±ÊêúÂ∞ãË∑ØÂæëÊ±∫ÂÆö(ÂèØ‰ª•Âà©Áî®search()Áü•ÈÅì)Ê±∫ÂÆö(‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØËºâÂÖ•ÁöÑÈ†ÜÂ∫è) namespace environment:ÊòØÂ•ó‰ª∂ÁöÑÂÖßÈÉ®‰ªãÈù¢„ÄÇpackage environment ÊéßÂà∂ÊàëÂÄëÂ¶Ç‰ΩïÊâæÂà∞ÂáΩÊï∏,ËÄånamespace environmentÊéßÂà∂ÂáΩÊï∏Â¶Ç‰ΩïÊâæÂà∞ËÆäÊï∏„ÄÇ  Âú®package environmentÁöÑÊØèÂÄãÁπ´Áµê‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Âú®namespace environment‰∏≠ÊâæÂà∞„ÄÇÈÄôÊ®£ÂèØ‰ª•Á¢∫‰øùÊØèÂÄãÂáΩÊï∏ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®Â•ó‰ª∂‰∏≠ÁöÑÂÖ∂‰ªñÂáΩÊï∏„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÊúâ‰∫õÁπ´ÁµêÂè™ËÉΩÂú®namespace ‰∏≠ÊâæÂà∞(‰æãÂ¶ÇÂÖßÈÉ®ÊàñÈùûËº∏Âá∫Áâ©‰ª∂),ÈÄôÁ®ÆÂÖßÈÉ®Áâ©‰ª∂ÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊòØÁî®‰æÜÈö±Ëóè‰∏Ä‰∫õÁπÅÁë£ÁöÑ‰∏î‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÁµ¶‰ΩøÁî®ËÄÖÁúãÂà∞ÁöÑÁ¥∞ÁØÄ„ÄÇ;
ÊØèÂÄãnamespace environment Êúâ‰∏ÄÊ®£ÁöÑÁ•ñÈõÜÂêà:
 ÊØèÂÄãnamespaceÊúâ imports ÁöÑÁí∞Â¢ÉÁâ©‰ª∂ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÂåÖÂê´‰∫ÜÂ•ó‰ª∂‰∏≠Áî®Âà∞ÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÂáΩÊï∏Áπ´Áµê„ÄÇËÄåÊâÄË¨ÇËº∏ÂÖ•Áí∞Â¢ÉÂØ¶ÈöõÁî±Â•óË£ùÈñãÁôº‰∫∫Âì°Âú®Ê™îÊ°àNAMESPACEÊåáÂÆö ÊòéÁ¢∫ÁöÑËº∏ÂÖ•ÊØèÂÄãbaseÂáΩÊï∏,ÂæàÁπÅÁë£,ÊâÄ‰ª•RÁõ¥Êé•Ë®≠ÂÆöimport enviromentÁöÑparentÊòØbase *namespae*[^1]„ÄÇ  The base namespace contains the same bindings as the base environment, but it has different parent. base namespace ÁöÑparentÊòØÁ∏ΩÈ´îÁí∞Â¢É(#global environment).ÂèÉËÄÉ‰∏ãÂúñ,ÈÄôÁ®ÆË®≠Ë®àÂ∞éËá¥Âú®import environment‰∏≠Êâæ‰∏çÂà∞Áπ´ÁµêÊôÇ,ÊúÉÈñãÂßãÂÜçÁ∏ΩÈ´îÁí∞Â¢É‰∏≠Â∞ãÊâæ,ËÄå‰πãÂâçÊèêÈÅéÁ∏ΩÈ´îÁí∞Â¢ÉÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊòØ‰∫íÂãïÁí∞Â¢É‰∏ãÂêçÁ®±ÊêúÂ∞ãÁöÑÈñãÂßãË∑ØÂæë,ÈÄô‰πüÂ∞éËá¥ÊêúÂ∞ãÁöÑÊñπÂºèÂèóÂà∞Â•ó‰ª∂ËºâÂÖ•È†ÜÂ∫èÁöÑÂΩ±Èüø„ÄÇÂõ†Ê≠§,RÊèê‰æõ‰∫Ü‰∫ÜR CMD check‰æÜË≠¶ÂëäÊ≠§Á®ÆÊÉÖÊ≥ÅÁöÑÁôºÁîü„ÄÇ(ÈõñÁÑ∂ÊúâÈ∫ªÁÖ©,‰ΩÜÊòØÁî±ÊñºS3 ÊñπÊ≥ïÁöÑdispatch Èóú‰øÇ,Ê≠§Á®ÆÊñπÂºè‰ªçÁÑ∂ÁïôËëó)  Á∂úÂêà‰∏äËø∞,ÂèØ‰ª•ÂæóÂà∞‰∏ãÂúñ:: ÊâÄ‰ª•Áï∂ sd() ÊêúÂ∞ãvar ÁöÑÂÄºÁöÑÊôÇÂÄô,ÊêúÂ∞ãÈ†ÜÂ∫èÊòØÂèóÂà∞ÈñãÁôºËÄÖÁöÑÊåáÂÆö(Âú®Ê™îÊ°àNAMESPACEÂà©Áî®import)ÔºåËÄå‰∏çÊúÉÂèóÂà∞Â•óË£ù‰ΩøÁî®ËÄÖÁöÑÂΩ±Èüø„ÄÇÈÄôÊ®£‰øùË≠âÊØèÊ¨°Â•ó‰ª∂Á®ãÂºèÁ¢ºÂü∑Ë°åÁöÑÊôÇÂÄô,ÈÉΩ‰∏ÄÊ®£,ËÄå‰∏çÊúÉÂèóÂà∞‰∏ÄËà¨‰ΩøÁî®ËÄÖËºâÂÖ•Â•ó‰ª∂ÁöÑÈ†ÜÂ∫èËÄåÂΩ±Èüø„ÄÇ
Ê≥®ÊÑèÂú®packageÂíånamespaceÂÖ©Á®ÆÁí∞Â¢É‰πãÈñìÊ≤íÊúâÁõ¥Êé•ÁöÑÈÄ£Áµê.ÈÄ£ÁµêÊòØÁî±ÂáΩÊï∏Áí∞Â¢ÉÂÆöÁæ©„ÄÇ
Execution environments execution environment. ‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∏Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ¨°Âü∑Ë°åÁöÑÊôÇÂÄôÊúÉÂÇ≥ÂõûÁîöÈ∫º?Á¨¨2Ê¨°Âë¢?
g <- function(x) {if (!env_has(current_env(), "a")) {message("Defining a")a <- 1} else {a <- a + 1}a} ÂÜç‰∏ÄÊ¨°Âà©Áî®‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑË™øÁî®,Á¢∫Ë™ç‰Ω†ÁöÑÁ≠îÊ°à:
g(10)#> Defining a#> [1] 1g(10)#> Defining a#> [1] 1g(11)#> Defining a#> [1] 1 ÈÄôÂÄãÂáΩÊï∏ÊØèÊ¨°Âü∑Ë°åÈÉΩÂÇ≥ÂõûüíØ‰∏ÄÊ®£ÁöÑÁ≠îÊ°à,ÂèÉËÄÉ a fresh start. ÊØèÊ¨°ÂáΩÊï∏Ë¢´Ë™øÁî®ÁöÑÊôÇÂÄô,‰∏ÄÂÄãÊñ∞ÁöÑÁí∞Â¢ÉÈÉΩÊúÉË¢´Âª∫Á´ã‰æÜ‰∏ªÂ∞éÂü∑Ë°å„ÄÇÈÄôÁ®ÆÁí∞Â¢ÉÁ®±ÁÇ∫Âü∑Ë°åÁí∞Â¢É„ÄÇËÄåÂü∑Ë°åÁí∞Â¢ÉÁöÑparentÁÇ∫ function environment.
Áî®Âè¶‰∏ÄÂÄãÁ∞°ÂñÆÈªûÁöÑ‰æãÂ≠êË™™Êòé. (Âúñ‰∏≠,Âü∑Ë°åÁí∞Â¢ÉÁöÑparentÈñìÊé•Ë°®Á§∫:Á∂ìÁî±ÂáΩÊï∏Áí∞Â¢É).
h <- function(x) {# 1.a <- 2 # 2.x + a}y <- h(1) # 3. Âü∑Ë°åÁí∞Â¢É(execution environment)Áü≠Êö´Â≠òÂú®,Áï∂ÂáΩÊï∏Âü∑Ë°åÂÆåÁï¢ÈÄöÂ∏∏ÊúÉË¢´GC„ÄÇÂú®ÂπæÁ®ÆÊÉÖÊ≥Å‰∏ã,ÊúÉÂú®Ë®òÊÜ∂È´îÂ≠òÂú®ÊØîËºÉ‰πÖ,Á¨¨‰∏ÄÁ®ÆÊòØÂõûÂÇ≥Áµ¶Âè¶‰∏ÄÂÄãËÆäÊï∏:
h2 <- function(x) {a <- x * 2current_env()}e <- h2(x = 10)env_print(e)#> <environment: 000000001D3DEF08>#> parent: <environment: global>#> bindings:#> * a: <dbl>#> * x: <dbl>fn_env(h2)#> <environment: R_GlobalEnv> Another way to capture it is to return an object with a binding to that environment, like a function. The following example illustrates that idea with a function factory, plus(). We use that factory to create a function called plus_one().
There's a lot going on in the diagram because the enclosing environment of plus_one() is the execution environment of plus().
plus <- function(x) {function(y) x + y}plus_one <- plus(1)plus_one#> function(y) x + y#> <environment: 0x000000001d7333a0> What happens when we call plus_one()? Its execution environment will have the captured execution environment of plus() as its parent:
plus_one(2)#> [1] 3 You'll learn more about function factories in functional programming.
Exercises   How is search_envs() different to env_parents(global_env())?
  Draw a diagram that shows the enclosing environments of this function:
f1 <- function(x1) {f2 <- function(x2) {f3 <- function(x3) {x1 + x2 + x3}f3(3)}f2(2)}f1(1)   Write an enhanced version of str() that provides more information about functions. Show where the function was found and what environment it was defined in.
  The call stack ÈÇÑÊúâÂè¶‰∏ÄÁ®ÆÁí∞Â¢ÉÁ®±ÁÇ∫ caller environment, ÂèØ‰ª•Á∂ìÁî± rlang::caller_env()Â≠òÂèñ„ÄÇ. This provides the environment from which the function was called, and hence varies based on how the function is called, not how the function was created. As we saw above this is a useful default whenever you write a function that takes an environment as an argument.
parent.frame() is equivalent to caller_env(); just note that it returns an environment, not a frame.To fully understand the caller environment we need to discuss two related concepts: the call stack, which is made up of frames. Executing a function creates two types of context. You've learned about one already: the execution environment is a child of the function environment, which is determined by where the function was created. There's another type of context created by where the function was called: this is called the call stack.
There are also a couple of small wrinkles when it comes to custom evaluation. See environments vs. frames for more details.
Simple call stacks Let's illustrate this with a simple sequence of calls: f() calls g() calls h().
f <- function(x) {g(x = 2)}g <- function(x) {h(x = 3)}h <- function(x) {stop()} The way you most commonly see a call stack in R is by looking at the traceback() after an error has occured:
f(x = 1)#> Error:traceback()#> 4: stop()#> 3: h(x = 3) #> 2: g(x = 2)#> 1: f(x = 1) Instead of stop() + traceback() to understand the call stack, we're going to use lobstr::cst() to print out the call stack tree:
h <- function(x) {lobstr::cst()}f(x = 1)#> ???#> ??Óúø?¬Äf(x = 1)#> ??Óúø?¬Äg(x = 2)#> ??Óúø?¬Äh(x = 3)#> ??Óúø?¬Älobstr::cst() This shows us that cst() was called from h(), which was called from g(), which was called from f(). Note that the order is the opposite from traceback(). As the call stacks get more compliated, I think it's easier to understand the sequence of calls if you start from the beginning, rather than the end (i.e. f() calls g(); rather than g() was called by f()).
Lazy evaluation The call stack above is simple - while you get a hint that there's some tree-like structure involved, everything happens on a single branch. This is typical of a call stack when all arguments are eagerly evaluated.
Let's create a more complicated example that involves some lazy evaluation. We'll create a sequence of functions, a(), b(), c(), that pass along an argument x.
a <- function(x) b(x)b <- function(x) c(x)c <- function(x) xa(f())#> ???#> ??Ó∞ß?¬Äa(f())#> ??? ??Óúø?¬Äb(x)#> ??? ??Óúø?¬Äc(x)#> ??Óúø?¬Äf()#> ??Óúø?¬Äg(x = 2)#> ??Óúø?¬Äh(x = 3)#> ??Óúø?¬Älobstr::cst() x is lazily evaluated so this tree gets two branches. In the first branch a() calls b(), then b() calls c(). The second branch starts when c() evaluates its argument x. This argument is evaluated in a new branch because the environment in which it is evaluated is the global environment, not the environment of c().
Frames Each element of the call stack is a frame2, also known as an evaluation context. The frame is an extremely important internal data structure, and R code can only access a small part of the data structure because it's so critical. A frame has three main components that are accessible from R:
  An expression (labelled with expr) giving the function call. This is what traceback() prints out.
  An environment (labelled with env), which is typically the execution environment of a function. There are two main exceptions: the environment of the global frame is the global environment, and calling eval() also generates frames, where the environment can be anything.
  A parent, the previous call in the call stack (shown by a grey arrow).
  (To focus on the calling environments, I have omitted the bindings in the global environment from f, g, and h to the respective function objects.)
The frame also holds exit handlers created with on.exit(), restarts and handlers for the condition system, and which context to return() to when a function completes. These are important for the internal operation of R, but are not directly accessible.
Dynamic scope Looking up variables in the calling stack rather than in the enclosing environment is called dynamic scoping. Few languages implement dynamic scoping (Emacs Lisp is a notable exception.) This is because dynamic scoping makes it much harder to reason about how a function operates: not only do you need to know how it was defined, you also need to know the context in which it was called. Dynamic scoping is primarily useful for developing functions that aid interactive data analysis. It is one of the topics discussed in non-standard evaluation.
Exercises  Write a function that lists all the variables defined in the environment in which it was called. It should return the same results as ls().  As data structures As well as powering scoping, environments are also useful data structures in their own right because they have reference semantics. There are three common problems that they can help solve:
  Avoiding copies of large data. Since environments have reference semantics, you'll never accidentally create a copy. This makes it a useful vessel for large objects. Bare environments are not that pleasant to work with; I recommend using R6 objects instead. Learn more in [R6].
  Managing state within a package. Explicit environments are useful in packages because they allow you to maintain state across function calls. Normally, objects in a package are locked, so you can't modify them directly. Instead, you can do something like this:
my_env <- new.env(parent = emptyenv())my_env$a <- 1get_a <- function() {my_env$a}set_a <- function(value) {old <- my_env$amy_env$a <- valueinvisible(old)} Returning the old value from setter functions is a good pattern because it makes it easier to reset the previous value in conjunction with on.exit() (see more in on exit).
  As a hashmap. A hashmap is a data structure that takes constant, O(1), time to find an object based on its name. Environments provide this behaviour by default, so can be used to simulate a hashmap. See the CRAN package hash for a complete development of this idea.
  <<- The ancestors of an environment have an important relationship to <<-. The regular assignment arrow, <-, always creates a variable in the current environment. The deep assignment arrow, <<-, never creates a variable in the current environment, but instead modifies an existing variable found by walking up the parent environments.
x <- 0f <- function() {x <<- 1}f()x#> [1] 1 If <<- doesn't find an existing variable, it will create one in the global environment. This is usually undesirable, because global variables introduce non-obvious dependencies between functions. <<- is most often used in conjunction with a closure, as described in Closures.
Exercises   What does this function do? How does it differ from <<- and why might you prefer it?
rebind <- function(name, value, env = caller_env()) {if (identical(env, empty_env())) {stop("Can't find `", name, "`", call. = FALSE)} else if (env_has(env, name)) {env_poke(env, name, value)} else {rebind(name, value, env_parent(env))}}rebind("a", 10)#> Error: Can't find `a`a <- 5rebind("a", 10)a#> [1] 10   Quiz answers   There are four ways: every object in an environment must have a name; order doesn't matter; environments have parents; environments have reference semantics.
  The parent of the global environment is the last package that you loaded. The only environment that doesn't have a parent is the empty environment.
  The enclosing environment of a function is the environment where it was created. It determines where a function looks for variables.
  Use caller_env() or parent.frame().
  <- always creates a binding in the current environment; <<- rebinds an existing name in a parent of the current environment.
  term global environment :Á∏ΩÈ´îÁí∞Â¢É package environments imports environment   You might wonder why rlang has env_poke() instead of env_set(). This is for consistency: _set() functions return a modified copy; _poke() functions modify in place. ↩︎
 NB: ?environment uses frame in a different sense: "Environments consist of a frame, or collection of named objects, and a pointer to an enclosing environment.". We avoid this sense of frame, which comes from S, because it's very specific and not widely used in base R. For example, the "frame" in parent.frame() is an execution context, not a collection of named objects. ↩︎

content:
ËÆÄÊ™î Âü∫Êú¨Ëº∏ÂÖ•ÂíåËº∏Âá∫ üòúÂèÉËÄÉÁ¨¨4ÈÉ®ÂàÜÂ≠ó‰∏≤‰∏ÄÁØÄ
 print() cat() sprintf()  a<-"hello"print(a)#> [1] "hello"print("hello")#> [1] "hello"b<-'ÈôåÁîü‰∫∫'print(b)#> [1] "ÈôåÁîü‰∫∫"print('hello')#> [1] "hello"cat(a)#> hellocat(b)#> ÈôåÁîü‰∫∫cat("ÈôåÁîü‰∫∫")#> ÈôåÁîü‰∫∫c<-paste0(a,b)print(c)#> [1] "helloÈôåÁîü‰∫∫"c<-paste0(a," ",b)print(c)#> [1] "hello ÈôåÁîü‰∫∫" print(),cat()ÈõñÁÑ∂Âú®‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑ‰æãÂ≠êÁúãËµ∑‰æÜ‰∏ÄÊ®£„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÂàùÂ≠∏ËÄÖÊé®Ëñ¶‰ΩøÁî®print()„ÄÇ

processFile = function(filepath) {con = file(filepath, "r")while ( TRUE ) {line = readLines(con, n = 1) # üè∑n=1 ÊØèÊ¨°ËÆÄÂÖ•‰∏ÄË°å if ( length(line) == 0 ) {break}print(line)}close(con)} Âà©Áî®Â•ó‰ª∂ËÆÄÂèñexcelÁöÑcsv read.csv("filename.csv", #name of fileheader = TRUE, #are there column names in 1st row?sep = ",", #what separates rows?as.is = !stringsAsFactors, #ÈóúÊéâÂ≠óÂÖÉËΩâfactorcolClasses = NA # to convert everything to character data set to "character"na.string = "NA" # could be "." for SAS filesskip = 0, #Ë¶ÅË∑≥ÈÅéÁöÑÂâçÂπæË°åÊï∏ÁõÆ>0strip.white = TRUE, #Êì†ÊéâÁ©∫ÁôΩ,‰æãÂ¶Ç " 0.1" = "0.1"fill = TRUE, #fill in rows that have unequal numbers of columnscomment.char = "#", #Ë®ªËß£‰∏çËÆÄÂÖ•stringsAsFactors = FALSE #ÊØîas.is Â∏∏Áî®,ÈóúÊéâÂ≠óÂÖÉËΩâfactor) read.csv()ÊúÄÁ∞°ÂñÆÁöÑÁî®Ê≥ïÊòØÁõ¥Êé•Áµ¶Ê™îÊ°àÂêçÁ®±,‰æãÂ¶Ç

#source("../../themes/variant/utils/r/hugoup.R")#knitr::opts_chunk$set(hugomd=T)#knitr::opts_chunk$set(collapse=T) ÂèÉËÄÉ ‰∏çÁõ∏Èóúhugodown  ÁõÆÁöÑ ÂàÜËß£ÈçµÂÄºÈÖçÂ∞ç,‰æãÂ¶Ç class=.w-75.ms-5,display=noneÊúâÂÖ©ÂÄãÈÖçÂ∞ç,ÂàÜÂà•ÊòØ
 class=.w-75.ms-5 display=none  ÊúâÂïèÈ°åÁöÑÁ§∫ÁØÑ x.source="class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none"regexec("(.*)=(.*)[ |,]?", x.source) #üè∑‚ùå  #> [[1]]#> [1] 1 1 26#> attr(,"match.length")#> [1] 29 24 4#> attr(,"index.type")#> [1] "chars"#> attr(,"useBytes")#> [1] TRUE Â∞çÁÖß
class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none123456789012345678901234567891 2  ÂÖ®ÈÉ® Á¨¨‰∏ÄÁµÑ Á¨¨‰∫åÁµÑ     1 1 26   29 24 4     x.source="class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none"nchar(x.source) # üè∑‰∏çÊòØlength()  #> [1] 29 matches = regexec("(.*)=(.*)[ |,]?", x.source) #üè∑‚ùå x.source="class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none"matches=regexec("(.*)=(.*)[ |,]?", x.source)for( m in matches){start<-mlen<-attr(m,"match.length")for (idx in 1:length(start)){print(substr(x.source,start[idx],start[idx]+len[idx]-1))}} #> [1] "class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none"#> [1] "class=.w-75.ms-5,display"#> [1] "none" ÈÄôË£°Âè™ÊâæÂà∞‰∏ÄÂÄã Ê≠£Á¢∫ÁöÑÊ®£Âºè‰πã‰∏Ä:([^=,]+)=([^=,]+)
x.source="class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none"matches = regexec("([^=,]+)=([^=,]+)", x.source)hugocmd("expand" ,'title="matchesÁöÑÂÖßÂÆπ" incode=true') #> matchesÁöÑÂÖßÂÆπ``````rmatches ``````#> [[1]]#> [1] 1 1 7#> attr(,"match.length")#> [1] 16 5 10#> attr(,"index.type")#> [1] "chars"#> attr(,"useBytes")#> [1] TRUE``````rhugocmd(m="expand" ,end=T)``````#>  for( m in matches){start<-mlen<-attr(m,"match.length")for (idx in 1:length(start)){print(substr(x.source,start[idx],start[idx]+len[idx]-1))}} #> [1] "class=.w-75.ms-5"#> [1] "class"#> [1] ".w-75.ms-5" class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none123456789012345678901234567891 2 ‚ùìÂè™ÊâæÂà∞‰∏ÄÂÄãkeypair, ‰ΩÜÊòØÁü•ÈÅìÊáâË©≤ÊúâÂÖ©ÂÄãKey pair
Â§™È∫ªÁÖ©,Âà©Áî®regmatches x.source="class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none"matches = regexec("([^=,]+)=([^=,]+)", x.source)regmatches(x.source, matches) #> [[1]]#> [1] "class=.w-75.ms-5" "class" ".w-75.ms-5" ÂÖ®ÈÉ®ÊâæÂá∫‰æÜ x.source="class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none"matches = gregexec("([^=,]+)=([^=,]+)", x.source)matches  x.source="class=.w-75.ms-5,display=none"nchar(x.source) # üè∑‰∏çÊòØlength()  #> [1] 29 matches = gregexec("([^=,]+)=([^=,]+)", x.source)regmatches(x.source, matches) #> [[1]]#> [,1] [,2] #> [1,] "class=.w-75.ms-5" "display=none"#> [2,] "class" "display" #> [3,] ".w-75.ms-5" "none" #> [[1]]#> [,1] [,2]#> [1,] 1 18 #üè∑keypair 2ÂÄã,ÂàÜÂà•Âú®‰ΩçÁΩÆ1,18 #> [2,] 1 18 #üè∑ÊØèÁµÑÁöÑKEY‰ΩçÁΩÆÂú®1,18 #> [3,] 7 26 #üè∑ÊØèÁµÑÁöÑvalue‰ΩçÁΩÆÂú®7 26  ÂïèÈ°å: Âè™Ë¶ÅKEYVALUE ?
token<-regmatches(x.source, matches)token<-unlist(token)keyvalue= token[c(F,T,T)]

Âü∫Êú¨Êìç‰Ωú  Êìç‰ΩúÈÄöÂ∏∏ÂíåË≥áÊñôÁµêÊßãÁõ∏Èóú,ÂèØ‰ª•ÂèÉËÄÉ Ë≥áÊñôÁµêÊßã

 Vectors Lists Matrices Arrays Factors Data Frames  ÊúÄÁ∞°ÂñÆÁöÑÊòØvectorÁâ©‰ª∂,atomic vector Êúâ6Á®Ædata types(ÊúâÊôÇ‰πüÂè´ÂÅö 6 ÂÄãclasses)
 Data Type Example     Logical TRUE, FALSE   Numeric 1.3, 5, 99   Integer 3L, 24L, 0L   Complex 5 + 4i   Character 'b' , "good", "TRUE", '23.4'   Raw "Hello" is stored as 48 65 6c 6c 6f    üí°: Â≠óÂÖÉHÂ∞çÊáâÁöÑ48ÊÄéÈ∫º‰æÜÁöÑ? Âà©Áî®JSÈ©óË≠â "H".charCodeAt(0).toString(16) ÔºåÂú®Ôº≤‰∏≠ÂèØ‰ª•Âà©Áî®charToRaw(ÁØÑ‰æã‰∏≠) Êï∏Â≠ó(3Á®Æ,‰æãÂ¶ÇÊï¥Êï∏„ÄÅÊµÆÈªû„ÄÅË§áÊï∏Ôºâ,ÈÇèËºØ,Â≠óÂÖÉ(2Á®ÆÔºåcharacter, raw)
v <- TRUE print(class(v))#> [1] "logical"v <- 23.5print(class(v))#> [1] "numeric"v <- 2Lprint(class(v))#> [1] "integer"v <- 2+5iprint(class(v))#> [1] "complex"v <- "TRUE"print(class(v))#> [1] "character"v <- charToRaw("Hello")„ÄÄ#üè∑üëèÂêåÊ®£ÁöÑ‰∏≠ÊñáÂ≠óÂà©Áî®charToRaw()ÊâæÂá∫‰æÜÁöÑÔºëÔºñÈÄ≤‰ΩçÔºåÊúÉÂõ†ÁÇ∫Á∑®Á¢ºËÄå‰∏çÂêå print(class(v))#> [1] "raw" üí° Êï∏Â≠óÔºì‰∏çÊòØÁúü‰πü‰∏çÊòØÂÅá
isTRUE(3)#> [1] FALSEisFALSE(3)#> [1] FALSE class(3),class(3.1) ÁöÑÈ°ûÂà•ÊòØÁîöÈ∫ºÔºüÊèêÁ§∫ numericÊåáÊ¥æ ÈõñÁÑ∂‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Áî®=‰ΩÜÊòØÔºåRÁöÑË®≠Ë®àÊòØ‰ΩøÁî®<-„ÄÇ
a <- 3 a<-3ÊòØ‰∏ÄÂÄãÊåáÊ¥æÁöÑÊïòËø∞Âè•,‰∏çÊúÉÂõûÈ•ãË≥áË®äÂà∞Ëû¢Âπï‰∏ä„ÄÇÂ¶ÇÊûúË¶ÅÁü•ÈÅìaÁöÑÂÖßÂÆπÊòØÁîöÈ∫º,Â∞±ÊâìÂÖ•a ÊàñËÄÖ(a<-3)
a#> [1] 3(a<-3)#> [1] 3 ‰∏ÄËà¨ÁöÑÊï∏Â≠∏ÂáΩÊï∏
b <- sqrt(a * a + 5)b#> [1] 3.741657 Âú®session‰∏≠ÁöÑÂ¶ÇÊûúË¶ÅÂàóÂá∫Â∑≤Á∂ìÂÆöÁæ©ÈÅéÁöÑËÆäÊï∏,ÂèØ‰ª•Âà©Áî®lsÔºàÁõ∏ÈóúÂáΩÊï∏rmÔºâ
ls()#> [1] "a" "b" "base_name" #> [4] "cachepath" "collectOutputClass" "collectSourceClass" #> [7] "debugp" "hugocmd" "indir" #> [10] "infile" "knit_print.data.frame" "ohook_chunk" #> [13] "ohook_output" "ohook_source" "one_string" #> [16] "outfile" "parseOutputHead" "parseSourceHead" #> [19] "relativePath" "splitLines" "wprint" a<-3 Êàñ a=3 ÁöÑÁ∞°ÂåñË™™Êòé ÊåâÁÖßRÁöÑË™™Êòé,Á≠âËôüÂè™ËÉΩÁî®Âú®top level,ÊàñÊòØÂáΩÊï∏ÂèÉÊï∏ÁöÑÊåáÂÆö„ÄÇÂèÉËÄÉ
‚Äπfunction_name‚Ä∫(‚Äπargname‚Ä∫ = ‚Äπvalue‚Ä∫, ‚Ä¶)‚Äπfunction_name‚Ä∫(‚Äπargs‚Ä∫, ‚Äπargname‚Ä∫ = ‚Äπvalue‚Ä∫, ‚Ä¶) ‰æãÂ¶Ç
mean(x<-1:10) #> [1] 5.5ls() # <span data-nopre class="codenote nopre">üè∑<span data-nopre class="tooltiptext" >üëèÂú®Â∑•‰ΩúÂçÄÊúÉÂá∫ÁèæxËÆäÊï∏ </span></span>rm(x)„ÄÄ# <span data-nopre class="codenote nopre">üè∑<span data-nopre class="tooltiptext" >üëèÂæûÂ∑•‰ΩúÂçÄÁßªÈô§ËÆäÊï∏x </span></span>mean(x=1:10) #> [1] 5.5ls() # <span data-nopre class="codenote nopre">üè∑<span data-nopre class="tooltiptext" >üëèÂ∑•‰ΩúÂçÄÊ≤íÊúâxËÆäÊï∏ÔºåÈÄôË£°Âè™ÊòØÂèÉÊï∏ÊåáÂÆöÔºåÂú®‰∏ªÊéßÂè∞Êï≤ÂÖ•ÔºümeanÂèØ‰ª•ÁúãÂà∞ÂèÉÊï∏Êúâx </span></span> ÈÅãÁÆó ÂõõÂâáÈÅãÁÆó ÂèÉËÄÉÂØ¶ÈöõÊìç‰Ωú
Logical ÈÇèËºØÈ°ûÂè™ÊúâÂÖ©ÂÄãÂÄº TRUE and FALSEÊàñÊòØÁ∞°ÂØ´Ôº¥ÔºåÔº¶:
a = TRUEtypeof(a)#> [1] "logical"b = FALSEtypeof(b)#> [1] "logical" RË™ûË®ÄÂ∏∏Áî®ÈÇèËºØÈÅãÁÆóÂ≠ê  operator Ë™™Êòé     < less than   > great than   <= less than or equal   >= greater than or equal   == equal to   != not equal to   | entry wise or   || or   ! not   & entry wise and   && and   xor(a,b) exclusive or     ÁØÑ‰æãÔºö‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÈÅãÁÆóÂ≠êÔºåÂú®ÂÄãÂà•ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂíåÊï¥ÂÄãÂêëÈáèÁöÑÈÅãÁÆóÁµêÊûú‰∏ç‰∏ÄÊ®£Ôºö
a = c(TRUE, FALSE)b = c(FALSE, F)a | b#> [1] TRUE FALSEa || b#> [1] TRUEa & b#> [1] FALSE FALSEa && b#> [1] FALSExor(a, b)#> [1] TRUE FALSE a||b, a&&b Âè™ÊØîÂ∞ça,b‰∏≠ÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†„ÄÇÂõ†Ê≠§Èï∑Â∫¶Âè™Êúâ1ÂÄã„ÄÇ‚úîÂ¶ÇÊûúÊòØÊµÅÁ®ãÊéßÂà∂,Â§ßÈ´î‰∏äÁî®ÁöÑÈÄôÂÖ©Á®Æ„ÄÇ
& Âíå | ÊØîÂ∞çÂÖÉÁ¥†,ÂÇ≥ÂõûÈï∑Â∫¶ÁÇ∫Â§ßÂ∞èÊúÄÈï∑ÁöÑÈÇ£ÂÄã„ÄÇ
0ÁÇ∫FALSE,ËÄå1ÁÇ∫TRUE„ÄÇÂú®R‰∏≠,Âà§Êñ∑‰∏ÄÂÄãËÆäÊï∏ÊòØÂê¶TRUE,Ë¶ÅÊ™¢Êü•Â•ΩÂπæÂÄãÂú∞Êñπ,Âõ†Ê≠§ÊúâÊèê‰æõÂÖßÂÆöÁöÑÊ™¢Êü•ÂáΩÊï∏‚úîisTRUE()
x <- c(TRUE,FALSE,0,6)y <- c(FALSE,TRUE,FALSE,TRUE)!xx&yx&&yx|yx||y #<span data-nopre class="codenote nopre">üè∑<span data-nopre class="tooltiptext" >üëèÂ∏∏Áî®ÊñºÈÇèËºØÂà§Êñ∑Âºè </span></span> ÊèêÁ§∫ > x <- c(TRUE,FALSE,0,6)#> [1] 1 0 0 6> y <- c(FALSE,TRUE,FALSE,TRUE)#> [1] FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE> !x#> [1] FALSE TRUE TRUE FALSE> x&y#> [1] FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE> x&&y#> [1] FALSE> x|y#> [1] TRUE TRUE FALSE TRUE> x||y#> [1] TRUE x <- c(TRUE,FALSE,0,6,0) # ÂÄãÊï∏ÊúâÔºïÂÄãy <- c(T,TRUE,FALSE,TRUE)„ÄÄ#„ÄÄÂÄãÊï∏ÊúâÔºîÂÄãx| y Ëß£Èáã‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑÁµêÊûú
 Èï∑Â∫¶ÁÇ∫ÁîöÈ∫ºÊòØÔºï ÊúÄÂæå‰∏ÄÂÄãÁÇ∫ÁîöÈ∫ºÊòØÔº¥ Â¶ÇÊûúx <- c(TRUE,FALSE,0,6,3) ÁÑ∂ÂæåÂïè x & y  ÊèêÁ§∫ Âæ™Áí∞Ë£úË∂≥ <-, <<-, =	ÂêëÂ∑¶ÊåáÊ¥æÂÄº„ÄÇ ->, ->>	ÂêëÂè≥ÊåáÊ¥æÂÄº„ÄÇ  Â§ßÈÉ®ÂàÜÊÉÖÊ≥Å‰∏ã<- Âíå = Âú®Áõ∏ÂêåÁöÑÁí∞Â¢É‰∏ãÁ≠âÂÉπ„ÄÇ ËÄå<<- Áî®‰æÜÊåáÊ¥æÂÄºÁµ¶Ë¶™‰ª£Áí∞Â¢É‰∏ãÁöÑËÆäÊï∏„ÄÇ
ÈÇèËºØÂáΩÊï∏ is.family ÂáΩÊï∏ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Áî®‰æÜÂà§ÂÆöËÆäÊï∏ÊòØ‰ªÄÈ∫ºÂûãÊÖãÔºåÂÇ≥ÂõûÁúüÂÅáÂÄºÔºå‰æãÂ¶Ç
a = c(1, 2, 3)is.numeric(a)#> [1] TRUEis.factor(a)#> [1] FALSEis.character(a)#> [1] FALSE ÂáΩÊï∏which()Âì™‰∫õÂÖÉÁ¥†‰∏ç‰∏ÄËá¥
which(A != C)#> Error in which(A != C): Êâæ‰∏çÂà∞Áâ©‰ª∂ 'A' ÂáΩÊï∏all() ÊòØ‰∏çÊòØÂêëÈáèÂÖßÊâÄÊúâÂÖÉÁ¥†ÈÉΩÊòØÔº¥
all(A==B)#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): Êâæ‰∏çÂà∞Áâ©‰ª∂ 'A'all(A==C)#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): Êâæ‰∏çÂà∞Áâ©‰ª∂ 'A' which(),all()Ë£°Èù¢ÁöÑÂèÉÊï∏ÂÖ∂ÂØ¶ÈÉΩÊòØÈÇèËºØÂêëÈáè„ÄÇË®ªËß£Ôºö‰ΩÜÊòØRË™ûË®ÄÁöÑÂêëÈáèÈÅãÁÆóÔºåÊ∂âÂèäËá™ÂãïÂ°´ÂÖÖÂæ™Áí∞ÔºåÂõ†Ê≠§Ê≥®ÊÑè‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑË®àÁÆóÁµêÊûú
D <- c("A","B","A","B")E <- c("A","B")all(D==E)#> [1] TRUEall(length(D)==length(E)) && all(D==E)#> [1] FALSE ÂáΩÊï∏identical(a,b) a,b ÊòØÂê¶Áõ∏Á≠â,ÊØîËºÉÁöÑÊòØÈô§‰∫Üa,bÁöÑÂÖßÂÆπ‰ª•Â§ñ,üí°ÈÇÑÊúâa b ÁöÑÂûãÊÖã„ÄÇ‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåidentical(1,as.integer(1)) ÁµêÊûúÊòØF,Âõ†ÁÇ∫ ÂâçËÄÖÊòØdouble,ÂæåËÄÖÊòØÊï¥Êï∏„ÄÇ
identical(1,as.integer(1)) #> [1] FALSEtypeof(1)#> [1] "double"identical(1L,as.integer(1)) #> [1] TRUE 1.
3=="3"#> [1] TRUEidentical(3,"3")#> [1] FALSE 2.
A <- c("A", "B", "C", "D")B <- AC <- c("A", "C", "C", "E")A==B#> [1] TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUEA==C #> [1] TRUE FALSE TRUE FALSEidentical(A,B) # üè∑üëèÂè™Êúâ‰∏ÄÂÄãÁúüÂÅáÂÄº #> [1] TRUEidentical(A,C)#> [1] FALSE   0.1+0.2 == 0.3 #F#> [1] FALSEidentical(0.1+0.2 , 0.3) #F#> [1] FALSE identical ÂèØ‰ª•ÂíåÂæåÈù¢ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∏all.equalÂáΩÊï∏ÊØîËºÉ„ÄÇ
ÂáΩÊï∏Á∑¥ÁøíÔºö
Â∞á‰∏äÈù¢ÂèØËÉΩÈÄ†ÊàêË™§Âà§ÁöÑÊÉÖÊ≥ÅÔºåÂØ´ÊàêÂáΩÊï∏ÂÖàÂà§Êñ∑ÊòØÂê¶Èï∑Â∫¶Áõ∏Á≠âÔºåÁÑ∂ÂæåÂà§Êñ∑ÂÖÉÁ¥†Áõ∏Á≠âÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âíåidentical()ÊØîËºÉ„ÄÇÊèêÁ§∫ hint: Âà©Áî®length
a <- character(0)identical(a, character(0)) # returns TRUEidentical(a, "") # returns FALSEidentical(a, numeric(0)) # returns also FALSE ÂØ¶Êï∏ÁöÑÊØîËºÉ ÂáΩÊï∏all.equal()
x <- seq(0, 1, by = 0.2)y <- seq(0, 1, by = 0.2)y[4]#> [1] 0.6x[3]#> [1] 0.41 - x[3]#> [1] 0.6y[4] == 1 - x[3]#> [1] FALSEy[4] > 1 - x[3]#> [1] TRUE## note:all.equal(y[4], 1 - x[3])„ÄÄ#> [1] TRUE## Q: what is the result of : 1-0.4 ==0.6 0.1+0.2 == 0.3 #‚õ≥Ë®ªËß£ #> [1] FALSEall.equal(0.1+0.2,0.3)#> [1] TRUE nx1<-numeric(0)nx2<-3is.null(nx1) # F,Âõ†ÁÇ∫nx1ÊòØÁ©∫ÂêëÈáè(Èï∑Â∫¶ÁÇ∫0ÁöÑÊï∏Â≠óÂêëÈáè)#> [1] FALSEis.na(nx1) # logical(0),ÊØèÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†Ê™¢Êü•ÊòØ‰∏çÊòØNA,‰ΩÜÊòØÁèæÂú®ÊòØÁ©∫ÂêëÈáè,ÊâÄ‰ª•ÁµêÊûúÊòØlogical(0)#> logical(0)typeof(nx1) # double#> [1] "double"typeof(nx2) # double#> [1] "double"length(nx1) # 0 #> [1] 0length(nx2) # 1#> [1] 1 ÁîöÈ∫ºÊôÇÂÄôÁî®Âà∞is.nullÊèêÁ§∫ config <- list()is.null(config) # <span data-nopre class="codenote nopre">üè∑<span data-nopre class="tooltiptext" >üëèÊòØempty(Á©∫ÁöÑ)listÁâ©‰ª∂,‰ΩÜ‰∏çÊòØnull(ËôõÁöÑ) </span></span>#> [1] FALSEis.null(config$name)#> [1] TRUE Á©∫ÁöÑÂíåËôõÁöÑÊúâÁîöÈ∫ºÂ∑ÆÂà•? ‰∏ÄÂÄãÊòØÂú®Ë®òÊÜ∂È´îÊúâ‰ΩçÁΩÆ,‰∏ÄÂÄãÊòØÊ≤íÊúâ„ÄÇvector Âà©Áî®cÂáΩÊï∏ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®vectorÂ≠òÊîæ‰∏ÄÂÄã‰ª•‰∏äÁöÑÊï∏Â≠ó„ÄÇ
a = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)a1 = 1:5 ÊúâÈóúvectorÁöÑÈÅãÁÆó:Âä†Ê∏õ‰πòÈô§Á≠âÁ≠â
a = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)a+1#> [1] 2 3 4 5 6a-1#> [1] 0 1 2 3 4a/2#> [1] 0.5 1.0 1.5 2.0 2.5a*3#> [1] 3 6 9 12 15 mean(a)#> [1] 3var(a)#> [1] 2.5summary(a)#> Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Âõ†Ê≠§Ë¶ÅÊ≥®ÊÑèÁöÑÊòØclassÈÄôÂÄãattribute„ÄÇÂú®Ôº≤‰∏≠ÔºåclassÊúâÂè¶‰∏ÄÂÄãÊÑèÊÄùÔºåÁî®‰æÜ‰ª£Ë°®Áâ©‰ª∂È°ûÂà•Ôºà‰æãÂ¶ÇË¶ÅËá™Ë®ÇÈ°ûÂà•ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âà©Áî®ÈÄôÂÄãclass)
data="string"class(data)#> character üè∑ÈÄôÊòØÂ≠ó‰∏≤ x=structure(data,class="risk") #üè∑üëèÁèæÂú®Áâ©‰ª∂xÁöÑÈ°ûÂà•‰∏çÂÜçÊòØÂ≠ó‰∏≤ÔºåËÄåÊòØÈ°ûÂà•risk class(x)#> risk üè∑Ê≠§ÊôÇÁöÑÈ°ûÂà•Ë¢´ËÆäÊõ¥Êàêrisk

title: 4.1.2_typeÁ∑¥Áøí
content:
Âú®R‰∏≠,options()Á∂ìÂ∏∏Áî®‰æÜË®≠ÂÆöÁ∏ΩÈ´îËÆäÊï∏,‰æãÂ¶ÇÂ•ó‰ª∂blogdownÂèØ‰ª•Ë®≠ÂÆöoptions(blogdown.method = 'custom')„ÄÇ
Â¶ÇÊûúÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÁü•ÈÅìÁõÆÂâçÁöÑË®≠ÂÆöÊÉÖÊ≥Å,ÂèØ‰ª•‰∏ãÊåá‰ª§options()Ôºå‰æãÂ¶Ç
options() # üè∑Ë®ªËß£ÈÄôÊòØÂú®Ë¶ñÁ™ó‰∏ãÂü∑Ë°åÁöÑÁµêÊûú  `options()`ÁöÑÂü∑Ë°åÁµêÊûú$add.smooth[1] TRUE$blogdown.author[1] ""$blogdown.ext[1] ".md"$blogdown.filename.pre_processor[1] NA$blogdown.files_filter[1] NA$blogdown.generator[1] NA$blogdown.hugo.args[1] NA$blogdown.hugo.dir[1] NA$blogdown.hugo.server[1] NA$blogdown.hugo.version[1] "0.84.4"$blogdown.initial_files[1] NA$blogdown.knit.on_save[1] TRUE$blogdown.knit.serve_site[1] NA(...ÁúÅÁï•...)$warning.length[1] 1000$width[1] 80$windowsTimeouts[1] 100 500  Â¶Ç‰∏äÂèØ‰ª•Áü•ÈÅìÊúâ‰∏ÄÂ§ß‰∏≤ÂàóË°®,Â¶ÇÊûúÊàëÂè™ÊÉ≥Áü•ÈÅìÂ•ó‰ª∂blogdownÁöÑË®≠ÂÆöÂàóË°®ÔºåË¶ÅÊÄéÊ®£ÂÅö? ‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØÊÄéÊ®£ÁØ©ÈÅ∏Âá∫ÊàëË¶ÅÁöÑË®≠ÂÆö?
 Ëß£Ê≥ï1:Âà©Áî®grep(),grepl() Ëß£Ê≥ï2:sapply , ‰πüÊòØÁî®Âà∞grep() ‰∏çËÉΩÁî® %in%  ÂèØ‰ª•ÂèÉËÄÉÈÄôË£°
ÊèêÁ§∫  Ëß£Ê≥ï1  olist<-options() # listokey<-names(olist) # vector # "blogdown" %in% okeyidx<-grep("blogdown",okey)olist[idx] #> $blogdown.method#> [1] "markdown"#> #> $blogdown.serve_site.startup#> [1] FALSE  Ëß£Ê≥ï2:Áúã‰∏Ä‰∏ãÁÇ∫ÁîöÈ∫º‰∏çËÉΩÁî® %in%  olist<-options() # listokey<-names(olist) # vector rst <- sapply(okey,function(item){"blogdown" %in% unlist(strsplit(item,"\\.")) })olist[rst] #> $blogdown.method#> [1] "markdown"#> #> $blogdown.serve_site.startup#> [1] FALSE  Ëß£ÈáãÈÄôË°å: rst <- sapply(okey,function(item){"blogdown" %in% unlist(strsplit(item,"\\.")) })
  \\.ËÄå‰∏çÊòØÂè™Êúâ. strsplit()Âü∑Ë°åÁöÑÁµêÊûúÊòØ‰∏ÄÂÄãlistËÄåÂàÜÈõ¢ÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥†Âú®Á¨¨‰∏ÄÂÄãnodeÊâÄ‰ª•,Áî®unlist %in%ÁöÑÁî®Ê≥ï  v=c("1.2","1.3")"1" %in% v #> [1] FALSE ‚õ≥Ë®ªËß£ ‚ùìÂú®‰∏ªÊéßÂè∞‰∏äÁöÑÊØîËºÉÂ§ö,‰ΩÜÊòØÂú®rmarkdown chunkÂè™ÊúâÁúãÂà∞ÂπæÂÄã,Âõ†ÁÇ∫Âú®rmarkdown‰∏≠Ê≤íÊúâËºâÂÖ•blogdownÂ•ó‰ª∂„ÄÇ
Á∑¥Áøí:ÊâæÂá∫ÁõÆÂâçÁöÑË™ûÁ≥ª Âà©Áî®l10n_info() ÊâæÂá∫ÁõÆÂâçÁöÑË™ûÁ≥ª,ËÄå‰∏çÊòØ‰∏ÄÈÄ£‰∏≤ÁúüÂÅáÂÄº„ÄÇÊèêÁ§∫ l10n_info()[2:3][(l10n_info()[2:3])==TRUE]

title: 4.1.3 type list
content:
List Lists ÊòØ‰∏ÄÂÄãRÁâ©‰ª∂„ÄÇÂÖ∂ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂÖßÂÆπÂèØ‰ª•ÊòØ‰∏çÂêåÂûãÊÖã,‰æãÂ¶Ç numbers, strings, vectors,matrix ÊàñËÄÖÊòØÂè¶‰∏ÄÂÄã listÔºåÁîöËá≥ÊòØÂáΩÊï∏„ÄÇ
Âª∫Á´ã List ÂáΩÊï∏list() ÂèØ‰ª•Âª∫Á´ãlist. list()‰∏≠ÁöÑÂèÉÊï∏Áî®ÈÄóÈªûÈöîÈñã,ÂπæÂÄãÂèÉÊï∏Â∞±ÂπæÂÄãNode„ÄÇ
list_data <- list("Red", "Green", c(21,32,11), TRUE, 51.23, 119.1)print(list_data)#> [[1]]#> [1] "Red"#> #> [[2]]#> [1] "Green"#> #> [[3]]#> [1] 21 32 11#> #> [[4]]#> [1] TRUE#> #> [[5]]#> [1] 51.23#> #> [[6]]#> [1] 119.1 Áµ¶‰∏≤Âàó‰∏≠ÁöÑÊØèÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂëΩÂêç list‰∏≠ÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂèØ‰ª•ÂëΩÂêç,ÁÑ∂ÂæåÁ∂ìÁî±ÂêçÁ®±Â≠òÂèñ„ÄÇ
#Âª∫Á´ã‰∏≤Âàó,ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÁöÑÂéüÁ¥†ÊúâÂêëÈáè,Áü©Èô£,Âíå‰∏ÄÂÄã‰∏≤Âàólist_data <- list(c("Jan","Feb","Mar"), matrix(c(3,9,5,1,-2,8), nrow = 2),list("green",12.3))# Áµ¶ÊØèÂÄãNODEÂëΩÂêçnames(list_data) <- c("1st Quarter", "A_Matrix", "A Inner list")#Show the list.print(list_data)#> $`1st Quarter`#> [1] "Jan" "Feb" "Mar"#> #> $A_Matrix#> [,1] [,2] [,3]#> [1,] 3 5 -2#> [2,] 9 1 8#> #> $`A Inner list`#> $`A Inner list`[[1]]#> [1] "green"#> #> $`A Inner list`[[2]]#> [1] 12.3 Â∏∂ÂêçÁöÑvectorÂíålist ,ÁôΩË©±ÊñáÊÑèÊÄùÂ∞±ÊòØÂ∞áÊØèÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂëΩÂêç„ÄÇ
x=c(1,2,3)names(x)<-c('a','b','c')x#> a b c #> 1 2 3    ÈÄôË£°Ë®éË´ñ‰∏Ä‰∏ãÁÇ∫ÁîöÈ∫ºÂú®RË™ûË®ÄÂ†ÖÊåÅ<-ËÄå‰∏çÊòØ=ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂÄãÂéüÂõ†
‰∏ÄËà¨ÁöÑÁ®ãÂºèË™ûË®Ä,‰∏çÊúÉÁî®Âà∞ÈÄôÁ®ÆÊñáÊ≥ï,‰æãÂ¶Ç,Âú®ÂÖ∂‰ªñÁ®ãÂºèË™ûË®Ä‰∏≠,Áõ¥Ë¶∫‰∏äÊáâË©≤ÊòØÊúâ‰∏ÄÂÄãnames(),ÁÑ∂ÂæåÁî®Ê≥ïÂ¶Ç‰∏ã:
names(x,c('a','b','c') ) üëπÂõ†Ê≠§<-‰∏çÈ°û‰ººÊåáÊ¥æ,ËÄåÊòØÈ°û‰ººÊµÅÂêëÊüêÂÄãÁâ©‰ª∂ÁöÑÂ±¨ÊÄß„ÄÇ
names()ÁöÑÂèÉÊï∏Â¶ÇÊûúÊòØmatrix,Ë¢´ÂëΩÂêçÁöÑÂ∞±ÊòØÊ¨Ñ‰Ωç(Áõ¥Ë°å)ÊàñÊòØÁ¥ÄÈåÑ(Ê©´Ë°å)?Á≠îÊ°àÊòØ‰ª•‰∏äÁöÜÈùû .ËÄåÊòØÁµ¶ÊØèÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂëΩÂêç„ÄÇ
x<-matrix(runif(9),nrow=3)names(x)<-c('a','b','c')x#> [,1] [,2] [,3]#> [1,] 0.5272366 0.7559570 0.4475868#> [2,] 0.6230506 0.2389823 0.3489261#> [3,] 0.8714734 0.3764245 0.2046041#> attr(,"names")#> [1] "a" "b" "c" NA NA NA NA NA NA names & matrixrownames(x)<-c('x','y','z')print(x,row.names=T)#> [,1] [,2] [,3]#> x 0.5272366 0.7559570 0.4475868#> y 0.6230506 0.2389823 0.3489261#> z 0.8714734 0.3764245 0.2046041#> attr(,"names")#> [1] "a" "b" "c" NA NA NA NA NA NA Âúñ‚ùìÂïè:Âú®‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑ‰æãÂ≠ê‰∏≠xÊòØ‰∏ÄÂÄãÁü©Èô£,x["a"]ÊúÉÂÇ≥ÂõûÁîöÈ∫º?
üìù ÂøÖÈ†àÊòØx[["a"]]ÂÇ≥ÂõûÁöÑÊâçÊòØÁ¥îÈáè,Âê¶Ââá‰ªçÁÑ∂ÊòØ‰∏ÄÂÄãlist
‰ΩÜÊòØÂú®data.frameÁöÑÁµêÊßã‰∏≠,names()<- Áµ¶ÂÆöÁöÑÊòØÊ¨Ñ‰ΩçÂêçÁ®±
xd<-data.frame(x)names(xd)<-c('a','b','c')xd#> a b c#> x 0.5272366 0.7559570 0.4475868#> y 0.6230506 0.2389823 0.3489261#> z 0.8714734 0.3764245 0.2046041 Â≠òÂèñ List ÂÖÉÁ¥† # 3ÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†,ÂàÜÂà•ÊòØlist, matrix, listlist_data <- list(c("Jan","Feb","Mar"), matrix(c(3,9,5,1,-2,8), nrow = 2),list("green",12.3))# Áµ¶ÂêçÁ®±names(list_data) <- c("1st Quarter", "A_Matrix", "A Inner list")# Access the first element of the list.print(list_data[1])#> $`1st Quarter`#> [1] "Jan" "Feb" "Mar"# Access the thrid element. As it is also a list, all its elements will be printed.print(list_data[3])#> $`A Inner list`#> $`A Inner list`[[1]]#> [1] "green"#> #> $`A Inner list`[[2]]#> [1] 12.3# Access the list element using the name of the element.print(list_data$A_Matrix)#> [,1] [,2] [,3]#> [1,] 3 5 -2#> [2,] 9 1 8 list ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑÂ≠òÂèñÂèØ‰ª•ÊòØ[[]] Êàñ $ ‰æãÂ¶Çx[["a"]], x$a„ÄÇ
‰∏ÄÂÄã‰∏ªË¶ÅÂàÜÂà•ÊòØ,list‰∏≠ÁöÑËôüÁ¢ºÁ¥¢Âºï,‰πüÊòØÂêçÁ®±,‰æãÂ¶Ç,ÂêëÈáèÁü©Èô£ÈÉΩÂèØ‰ª•ÊòØx[1]ÊãøÂà∞Á¥îÈáè,‰ΩÜÊòØlist x[1]ÊãøÂà∞ÁöÑ‰ªçÁÑ∂ÊòØlist„ÄÇËôïÁêÜlist ÂÖÉÁ¥† listÁöÑÂä†ÂÖ•ÂíåÂà™Èô§,Âè™ËÉΩÂú®Â∞æÁ´ØÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÊõ¥ÊîπË≥áÊñô‰∏çÂèóÈôêÂà∂„ÄÇ
# Create a list containing a vector, a matrix and a list.list_data <- list(c("Jan","Feb","Mar"), matrix(c(3,9,5,1,-2,8), nrow = 2),list("green",12.3))# Give names to the elements in the list.names(list_data) <- c("1st Quarter", "A_Matrix", "A Inner list")# Âä†ÂÖ•ÂÖÉÁ¥†list_data[4] <- "New element"print(list_data[4])#> [[1]]#> [1] "New element"# üîëÁßªÈô§ÊúÄÂæå‰∏ÄÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†list_data[4] <- NULL# Print the 4th Element.print(list_data[4])#> $<NA>#> NULL# Update the 3rd Element.list_data[3] <- "updated element"print(list_data[3])#> $`A Inner list`#> [1] "updated element" Merging Lists You can merge many lists into one list by placing all the lists inside one list() function.
# Create two lists.list1 <- list(1,2,3)list2 <- list("Sun","Mon","Tue")# Merge the two lists.merged.list <- c(list1,list2)# Print the merged list.print(merged.list)#> [[1]]#> [1] 1#> #> [[2]]#> [1] 2#> #> [[3]]#> [1] 3#> #> [[4]]#> [1] "Sun"#> #> [[5]]#> [1] "Mon"#> #> [[6]]#> [1] "Tue" ‚ùì Âú®Â§ßÈÉ®ÂàÜÁ®ãÂºèË™ûË®Ä‰∏≠,ÂêëÈáèÁöÑÊÑèÊÄù,Âè™Ë¶ÅÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂêåÂûãÊÖãÂ∞±Ë°å„ÄÇÂèàÔºåÊàëÂÄëÂ∑≤Á∂ìÁü•ÈÅì,ÂáΩÊï∏cÂèØ‰ª•Áî¢ÁîüÂêëÈáè„ÄÇ‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑÁ®ãÂºèÁ¢º‰∏≠,Âà©Áî®cÂ∞áÂÖ©ÂÄãlist Âêà‰Ωµ,ÊàëÂÄëÊåâÁÖßÂ§ßÈÉ®ÂàÜÁ®ãÂºèË™ûË®ÄÁöÑËßÄÂøµÁü•ÈÅì,Êó¢ÁÑ∂ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÈÉΩÊòØÁõ∏ÂêåÂûãÊÖã(ÈÉΩÊòØlist),ÈÇ£Â∞±ÊòØ2ÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†Ôºå‰ΩÜÊòØÁèæÂú®ÊòØ6ÂÄã,ÁÇ∫ÁîöÈ∫º?
üëç ÂáΩÊï∏c()ÊòØ‰∏ÄÂÄãÂ§öÂûãÂáΩÊï∏(Áâ©‰ª∂Ë™ûË®Ä‰∏≠ÁöÑË¨õÊ≥ïÂ∞±ÊòØÊ†πÊìöÂèÉÊï∏ÁöÑ‰∏çÂêå,ËÄåÊúâ‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÁµêÊûú)„ÄÇÈÄôË£°ÁöÑÁµêÊûúÊòØ6ÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†„ÄÇÊØèÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†ÈÉΩÊòØlist(Ë≠âÊòé:list)„ÄÇ
 ‚ùìÂ¶ÇÊûúË¶Å2ÂÄã?  üìù ÈÇ£Â∞±ÊòØmerged.list2<-list(list1,list2)„ÄÇ   ‚ùì merge.list<-c(x,y) ‰∏≠ÁöÑmergeÊòØ‰∏çÊòØÁâ©‰ª∂ÁöÑÊÑèÊÄù?  üëç ‰∏çÊòØ„ÄÇÂè™ÊòØÂÄãÂêàÊ≥ïÁöÑËÆäÊï∏„ÄÇ    ‚ùì ÂØ´‰∏ÄÂÄãÂáΩÊï∏,Âêà‰ΩµÂÖ©ÂÄãlist,‰ΩÜÊòØË¶ÅÊ±ÇÂÖ©ÂÄãlist‰∏≠ÊúâÂêåÂêçÁöÑÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂøÖÈ†àÊòØÁ¨¨2ÂÄã‰∏≠ÁöÑÂêçÁ®±„ÄÇ‰æãÂ¶Ç list(a=1,b=2,c=3), list(b=4) Âêà‰ΩµÂæåËÆäÊàê a=1,b=4,c=3„ÄÇ
üìù
merge_list = function(x, y) {x[names(y)] = yx} List ËΩâ Vector ÂáΩÊï∏ unlist()
# Create lists.list1 <- list(1:5) # üè∑‰∏çÊòØÁî¢Áîü5ÂÄãNODELÁöÑ‰∏≤Âàó,ËÄåÊòØÂÖàÁî¢Áîü5ÂÄãÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑÂêëÈáè,ÁÑ∂ÂæåÊîæÂà∞Á¨¨‰∏ÄÂÄãÁØÄÈªû print(list1)#> [[1]]#> [1] 1 2 3 4 5list2 <-list(10:14)print(list2)#> [[1]]#> [1] 10 11 12 13 14# Convert the lists to vectors.v1 <- unlist(list1)v2 <- unlist(list2)print(v1)#> [1] 1 2 3 4 5print(v2)#> [1] 10 11 12 13 14# Now add the vectorsresult <- v1+v2print(result)#> [1] 11 13 15 17 19 ‚ùì Â¶ÇÊûúÊòØlist‰∏≠ÁöÑÂÖßÂÆπÊúâ‰∏ç‰∏ÄÊ®£ÁöÑÂûãÊÖãÂë¢?‰æãÂ¶Ç
x<-list("a",1)y<-unlist(x)typeof (y)#> [1] "character" ÊØîËºÉvector, list‰∏≠,Â≠ó‰∏≤ÁöÑÂïèÈ°å  Q length()ÂáΩÊï∏ÂèØ‰ª•Áü•ÈÅìvector,list ÁöÑÈï∑Â∫¶,‰ΩÜÊòØÁÇ∫ÁîöÈ∫ºlength("hello")ÁöÑÈï∑Â∫¶ÊòØ1?  a<-c("hello","r")length(a) #üí°#> [1] 2length(a[1]) #üí°#> [1] 1length(a[[1]]) #üí°#> [1] 1nchar(a[1]) #üîë#> [1] 5length("hello") #‚ùì#> [1] 1 Âúñ Q  a<-list("hello","r")length(a)#> [1] 2length(a[1])#> [1] 1length(a[[1]])#> [1] 1typeof("xxx") #üí°#> [1] "character"typeof(1) #üí°#> [1] "double"typeof(1L) #üí°#> [1] "integer" ‰∏äÈù¢ÂÖ©ÂÄãÁ≠îÊ°àÁöÑÂïèÈ°å,ÂíåRÊÄéÊ®£Âª∫Á´ãÂ≠ó‰∏≤ÊúâÈóú üìùÁ∏Ω‰πã,Â≠ó‰∏≤Èï∑Â∫¶ÂáΩÊï∏üîënchar()„ÄÇ
data set build in List of pre-loaded data data() Loading a built-in R data
data(mtcars)  nrow(mtcars)#> [1] 32ncol(mtcars)#> [1] 11 Á∑¥Áøí ÊãøÂÖÉÁ¥† [ Â§ßÊ¶ÇÊ∂µËìã‰∫ÜÊâÄÊúâÂ≠òÂèñÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÂèÉËÄÉ
‚ùìÂ¶ÇÊûúË≥áÊñôÂ¶Ç‰∏ã,
> dataV1 V21 12.448 13.9192 22.242 4.6063 24.509 0.176 Ââá‰∏ãÈù¢Êåá‰ª§ÂàÜÂà•ÊãøÂà∞ÁîöÈ∫º?
data[1,1]data[1,"V1"]data$V1[1]data[[1]][1]data[["V1"]][1]

title: 4.4.1 json

title: 8.1. Ëá™Ë£ΩÂ•ó‰ª∂

Áõ∏Èóú Ëá™Ë£Ω package  R ÂåÖË£Ω‰Ωú package example R packages book on documentation
(Hilary Parker's is the classic), and if you're in the second camp you probably already know what you're doing (and if not, Hadley Wickham's R packages book is an excellent and thorough guide).  Ê∏¨Ë©¶debug  RTVS debug ‰∫íÂãïR document  Ëá™Ë£Ω package ÁØÑ‰æã  Êú¨ÁØÑ‰æã‰∏≠package Âè™Êúâ‰∏ÄÂÄãdata.frame,‰∏ÄÂÄãÂáΩÊï∏. Âü∑Ë°åÂÆåpackage.seleton()‰ª•Âæå,ÂøÖÈ†àÂú®manÂ≠êÁõÆÈåÑ‰∏≠‰øÆÊîπÊØèÂÄãRDÊ™îÊ°à,titleË£°Èù¢ÂøÖÈ†àÊúâÂÖßÂÆπ„ÄÇ ÁÑ∂ÂæåÊâçÂü∑Ë°åbuild()  ÁØÑ‰æãÈúÄË¶ÅÁöÑÊ™îÊ°àÔºö trees91.csv
rm(list = ls())ufc <- read.csv('./resource/trees91.csv')vol.m3 <- function(dbh.cm, height.m, multiplier = 0.5) {vol.m3 <- pi * (dbh.cm / 200) ^ 2 * height.m * multiplierreturn(vol.m3)}package.skeleton(name = "xxx", path = "./packages", force = TRUE)library(devtools)build("./packages/xxx")build("./packages/xxx", binary = TRUE) Â•ó‰ª∂ÁöÑÁõÆÈåÑÁµêÊßã Rstudio, package devtools , RMD Â∏∏Ë≠ò„ÄÇ
 ÊúÄÂ∞ëÈ†àÈúÄË¶ÅÂÖ©ÂÄãÂ≠êÁõÆÈåÑ ÊúÄÂ∞èÁöÑÂ•ó‰ª∂‰∏ÄËà¨ÂåÖÊã¨‰∏ÄÂÄãÊ†πÁõÆÈåÑÔºå‰∏ãÊúâ‰∏ÄÂÄãÂ≠êÁõÆÈåÑR\Ôºå‰∏ÄÂÄãÊ™îÊ°à DESCRIPTION(packageÂè´‰ªÄÈ∫ºÂêçÂ≠êÔºå‰æùË≥¥ÊñºÂì™‰∫õÂÖ∂‰ªñÂ•ó‰ª∂). Áï∂ËºâÂÖ•Â•ó‰ª∂ÁöÑÊôÇÂÄôÔºåÊúÉÂü∑Ë°åÂ•ó‰ª∂‰∏≠‰ΩçÊñºÂ≠êÁõÆÈåÑR/‰∏≠ÁöÑ.R„ÄÇ ‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÂåÖÂê´Ë≥áÊñô  Ë≥áÊñô‰∏ÄËà¨‰ΩçÊñºÂ≠êÁõÆÈåÑ data/ ‰∏≠„ÄÇÂâØÊ™îÂêç‰∏ÄËà¨ÊòØ.RData, .csv, .R„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØ‰∏çÂèóÈôêÂà∂„ÄÇ    note: 2,3 ÁöÑ‰∏çÂêåÊòØÔºåÂæåËÄÖÁõ¥Êé•Â∞éÂÖ•globalÁ©∫Èñì„ÄÇ
‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑÂÅöÊ≥ïÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ËóâÁî±Â•ó‰ª∂ÁöÑÂπ´Âä©ÈÅîÊàêÈÅîÊàêÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÂà©Áî®devtools Âª∫Á´ãÈ™®Êû∂(package skeleton)
 Âª∫Á´ãÂ•ó‰ª∂È™®Êû∂ devtools::create('~/mypackage'). Á∑®ËºØ DESCRIPTION. Á®ãÂºèÁ¢ºÊîæÂÖ•Â≠êÁõÆÈåÑ R/.  Â∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÁ®ã Ê∏¨Ë©¶ Â¶ÇÊûúÁõÆÂâçÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÁõÆÈåÑÂ∞±ÊòØÂ•ó‰ª∂Ê†πÁõÆÈåÑÔºåÈÇ£È∫ºÂä†ÂÖ•Ë≥áÊñôÂíåÂØ´ÂÆåÁ®ãÂºèÁ¢º‰ª•ÂæåÔºåÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®Êåá‰ª§devtools::load_all()ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊòØÂú®Rstudio‰∏≠,Áõ¥Êé•Âà©Áî®install and restart Â∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ËºâÂÖ•‰øÆÊîπÂÆå‰ª•ÂæåÁöÑÊÉ°È©ó„ÄÇ„ÄÇÂèØ‰ª•ÂèÉËÄÉÈÄôË£°„ÄÇ
Installed package workflow Â¶ÇÊûúÂ•ó‰ª∂Â∑≤Á∂ìÂÆâË£ùÔºå‰∏¶‰∏îË¢´ÂÖ∂‰ªñÁöÑÂ∞àÊ°à‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®ÔºåÈÇ£È∫ºÁ®ãÂºèÁ¢ºËÆäÂãïÁöÑË©±ÔºåÂ∞±ÂøÖÈ†à3ÂÄãÊ≠•È©ü
 Edit code (or add data). Re-generate documentation and namespace: devtools::document('/path/to/pkg') Install: devtools::install('/path/to/pkg'). Reload: devtools::reload(inst('pkg')).  Documentation and exports Áï∂Â•óÂª∫Á´ãÁî®Êåá‰ª§library()ËºâÂÖ•ÊôÇÔºåÈ†êË®≠‰∏äÔºåÊâÄÊúâÁöÑËÆäÊï∏ÂíåÂáΩÊï∏ÈÉΩÊòØ private ‰∏¶‰∏çÊúÉË¢´Âä†ÂÖ•Âà∞ globalÁí∞Â¢É„ÄÇ ËÄåÊ™îÊ°àNAMESPACE ÂâáÊòØÁî®‰æÜÊåáÂÆöË¶Å__public__ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∏„ÄÇ Â¶ÇÊûú‰∏çÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÊâãÂãïÁ∑®ËºØÊ™îÊ°àNAMESPACEÔºåÂâáÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®ÁâπÊÆäÊåá‰ª§ÔºåÁî¢ÁîüÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÁöÑÊ†ºÂºèÔºö
#' Short description of what this does#'#' Longer description of what this does. Approximately a paragraph.#'#' @param x The first thing#' @param y The second thing.#' @return The thing that comes out of this function#'#' @export (do export this in NAMESPACE)a_function <- function(x,y) {return x+y} ÁÑ∂ÂæåÂà©Áî®Êåá‰ª§Ôºå devtools::document(), ÊúÉËá™ÂãïÊõ¥Êñ∞ NAMESPACE ‰∏¶Âª∫Á´ãÂáΩÊï∏Áõ∏ÈóúÁöÑË™™ÊòéÊ™î„ÄÇ‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºå man/a_function.Rd. ÈÄôÊ®£ÈÄôÂÄãÂáΩÊï∏ÔºåÂ∞±ÂÉèÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰∏ÄËà¨ÁöÑÂáΩÊï∏‰∏ÄÊ®£ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Ê±ÇÂä©Ôºå‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Âú®Êåá‰ª§library()‰πãÂæåÂëºÂè´Ë™øÁî®„ÄÇ
Â¶ÇÊûúÂè™ÊòØËá™Ë°åÊ∏¨Ë©¶ÔºåÊåá‰ª§ devtools::load_all()Â∞±ÂèØ‰ª•‰∫Ü„ÄÇ ‰ΩÜÊòØÈÄöÂ∏∏Ë¶ÅÊï£ÁôºÔºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØÂà©Áî® devtools::install() ÂÆâË£ùÂ•ó‰ª∂„ÄÇ
Ë≥áÊñôÊîæÂÖ•Â•ó‰ª∂ ÊúÄÁ∞°ÂñÆÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÔºåÁõ¥Êé•Â∞áË≥áÊñôÊ™î (.RData, .csv, etc.)ÁΩÆÊñº data/Â≠êÁõÆÈåÑ„ÄÇ
ÊØîËºÉ‰∏çÊúÉÂá∫ÈåØÁöÑÊñπÂºèÊòØÂà©Áî®usethisÂ•ó‰ª∂ÔºàÂèñ‰ª£ËàäÁâà devtools )„ÄÇ Âü∫Êú¨‰∏äÁî®Âà∞ÂÖ©ÂÄãÂáΩÊï∏
userthis::use_data_raw()userthis::use_data()  usethis::use_data_raw()ÔºåÊúÉÂª∫Á´ãÂ≠êÁõÆÈåÑdata-raw/: Âú®data-raw/Â≠êÁõÆÈåÑ‰∏≠ÔºåÊîæÈÄ≤ÈùûRÊ†ºÂºèÁöÑË≥áÊñôÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåcsvÊ™îÊ°à„ÄÇ ËôïÁêÜË≥áÊñôÁöÑÁ®ãÂºèÁ¢ºÔºå‰ªªÊÑèRscript ÂêçÁ®±ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂæåÊâãÂãïÂü∑Ë°åÔºåÔºà‰∏çÊúÉË¢´Ëá™ÂãïÂü∑Ë°åÔºâÁΩÆÊñº data-raw/ ÔºåÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÔºö  experiment1 <-read.csv('expt1.csv') usethis::use_data(experiment1) This saves data/experiment1.RData in your package directory (make sure you've setwd() to the package directory...)

title: 9.1 Plot more
content:
Êõ¥Â§öÁπ™Âúñ Áπ™ÂúñÂçÄ‰∏≠ÁöÑÂ≠ó‰∏≤ ÂáΩÊï∏ text() Âú®Áπ™ÂúñÂçÄÂ°´ÂÖ•Â≠ó‰∏≤,Á∞°ÂåñÁöÑÊåá‰ª§Â¶Ç‰∏ã:

x and y: ÊñáÂ≠óÂ∫ßÊ®ô;
labels: ‰æãÂ¶Ç "a label"
pos: ‰∏ãÂ∑¶‰∏äÂè≥Ôºå1234
cex: ÊîæÂ§ßÂÄçÊï∏Ôºå‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºå0.65„ÄÇ
ÁØÑ‰æã :
d<-head(mtcars)plot(d[,'wt'], d[,'mpg'], main="Milage vs. Car Weight\n~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~",xlab="Weight", ylab="Miles/(US) gallon",pch=19, col="darkgreen")text(d[,'wt'], d[,'mpg'], row.names(d), cex=1,pos=3,col="red")  Âú®ÂúñÂΩ¢margin‰∏≠Â°´ÂÖ•ÊñáÂ≠ó mtext(text, side=3) text : ‰æãÂ¶Ç"a label" side : Âì™‰∏ÄÂÅ¥ :
È†ÜÊôÇÈáù 1: ‰∏ã 2: Â∑¶ 3: ‰∏ä 4: Âèà
ÁØÑ‰æã :
plot(1:10, 1:10, main="mtext(...) examples\n~~~~~~~~~~~")mtext("Magic function", side=3) Add mathematical annotation to a plot plot(1:10, 1:10, main="text(...) examples\n~~~~~~~~~~~")text(4, 9, expression(hat(beta) == (X^t * X)^{-1} * X^t * y))text(7, 4, expression(bar(x) == sum(frac(x[i], n), i==1, n))) ÂáΩÊï∏Áï´Âúñ eq = function(x){x*x}plot(eq(1:1000), type='l') ÂïèÈ°åÊòØÂ¶ÇÊûúxÂ∫ßÊ®ôÁöÑÂ¢ûÂä†‰∏çÊòØ1ÂñÆ‰Ωç?
x<-seq(1,10,0.1)y<-exp(x)x<-yeq = function(x){x*x}plot(x,eq(x), type='l') plot()ÁöÑÂèÉÊï∏ÂèØ‰ª•ÊòØy ÊàñÂÖ©ÂÄãÂèÉÊï∏(x,y),‰ΩÜÊòØÂáΩÊï∏curv()ÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂÄãÂèÉÊï∏ÊòØexpr,‰∏çÊòØy„ÄÇ
„äôÔ∏è Â¶ÇÊûú‰∏çÊåáÂÆöfrom,to,ÊàñËÄÖadd=T,ÂÖßÂÆöÊòØÂæû0Âà∞1„ÄÇ
eq = function(x){x*x}curve(eq, from=1, to=50, xlab="x", ylab="y")  ‚ùì1 Ëß£Èáã‰∏ãÈù¢ÂÖ©ÂÄãÁ®ãÂºèÂçÄÂ°äÁÇ∫‰ΩïÈåØË™§?Â¶Ç‰Ωï‰øÆÊ≠£?  eq = function(x){x*x}y<-eq(1:50)curve(y, xlab="x", ylab="y")#> Error in y(x): Ê≤íÊúâÈÄôÂÄãÂáΩÂºè "y"  ‚ùì2‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑÈåØË™§?  eq = function(x){x*x}z<-1:50curve(eq(z), xlab="x", ylab="y") Error in curve(eq(z), xlab = "x", ylab = "y") : 'expr' must be a function, or a call or an expression containing 'x'
üíØ‰∏äÈù¢ÁöÑeq() („äôÔ∏è ÈÄôÂÄãÂèÉÊï∏ÊúÉË¢´ËΩâÊàêexpression ËÄåÈÄôÂÄãË°®ÈÅîÂºèÈúÄË¶Åsymbol x),ËÄåÂáΩÊï∏‰∏≠ÁöÑËÆäÊï∏Â¶ÇÊûúÊòØzÂ∞±Êâæ‰∏çÂà∞ÁÑ∂ÂæåÁôºÁîüÈåØË™§„ÄÇ
solution:
curve(eq(z),xname="z", xlab="x", ylab="y") plot example Ê≠£Â∏∏
polyred = curve(dnorm(x), xlim = c(-4,4)) polygon(polyred$x, polyred$y, col = "red") ‚ùì Ëß£Èáã‰∏ãÈù¢ÂÖ©ÂÄã,Á¨¨‰∏ÄÂÄãÊòØÈåØÁöÑ
‚ùå ÈÄô‰∏çÊòØÊàëÂÄëË¶ÅÁöÑÂúñ
eq = function(x){x*x}y<-eq(1:50)curve(eq, 1,50,xlab="x", ylab="y",lwd=5,col="yellow")polygon(1:50,y,lty=2,col="red") ‚≠ï
eq = function(x){x*x}y<-eq(1:50)curve(eq, 1,50,xlab="x", ylab="y",lwd=5,col="yellow")polygon(c(1:50,50),c(y,0),lty=2,col="red") üíØ Á¨¨‰∏ÄÂÄãÈªûÂíåÊúÄÂæå‰∏ÄÂÄãÈªûÊúÉÈÄ£Âú®‰∏ÄËµ∑„ÄÇÁÑ∂ÂæåÂ°´Ëâ≤„ÄÇ
rug set.seed(3)x <- rbeta(150, 3, 25)#png("rug.png")hist(x)rug(quantile(x)[2:4], col=2, lwd=2.5) # È†êË®≠ÊòØ "0%" "25%" "50%" "75%" "100%" set.seed(3)x <- rbeta(150, 3, 25)#png("rug.png")hist(x)abline(v= quantile(x)[2:4],lty="dotted",col="red" )xpos= quantile(x)[2:4]text(xpos[1],0, "25%")text(xpos[2],0, "50%")text(xpos[3],0, "75%") Á∑¥Áøí par(mfrow=c(2,2))plot(dnorm(x),xlim=c(-4,4))plot(pnorm(x),xlim=c(-4,4))plot(qnorm(x),xlim=c(-4,4))plot(rnorm(x),xlim=c(-4,4)) ÂúñÂΩ¢Â≠òÊ™î ÂèØ‰ª•Âà©Áî®menuÂ≠òÊ™îÔºå‰æãÂ¶ÇFile -> Save As. ‰πüÂèØ‰ª•Âà©Áî®ÂáΩÊï∏Ôºö  Function Output to     pdf("mygraph.pdf") pdf file   win.metafile("mygraph.wmf") windows metafile   png("mygraph.png") png file   jpeg("mygraph.jpg") jpeg file   bmp("mygraph.bmp") bmp file   postscript("mygraph.ps") postscript file    
# Give the chart file a name.png(file = "scatterplot_matrices.png")# Plot the matrices between 4 variables giving 12 plots.# One variable with 3 others and total 4 variables.pairs(~wt+mpg+disp+cyl,data = mtcars,main = "Scatterplot Matrix")# Save the file.dev.off()

title: MC_Âü∫Êú¨
content:
‰∫ÇÊï∏ # Sample from a standard normal RV with sample size n=5:rnorm(5)# A different sample from the same distribution:rnorm(5)# Set the seed of the random number generator and take two samples:set.seed(6254137)rnorm(5)rnorm(5)# Reset the seed to the same value to get the same samples again:set.seed(6254137)rnorm(5)rnorm(5) ÊäΩÊ®£ rbinom(10,1,0.5) # Bernouli rnorm(10) # normal ÈáçË§áÊäΩÊ®£
# Set the random seedset.seed(123456)# initialize ybar to a vector of length r=10000 to later store results:r <- 10000ybar <- numeric(r)# repeat r times:for(j in 1:r) {# Draw a sample and store the sample mean in pos. j=1,2,... of ybar: sample <- rnorm(100,10,2)ybar[j] <- mean(sample)} ÁµêÊûúÂàÜÊûê
# The first 20 of 10000 estimates:ybar[1:20]# Simulated mean:mean(ybar)# Simulated variance:var(ybar)# Simulated density:plot(density(ybar))curve( dnorm(x,10,sqrt(.04)), add=TRUE,lty=2) Ê®°Êì¨‰º∞Ë®à # Set the random seedset.seed(123456)# Draw a sample given the population parameterssample <- rnorm(100,10,2)# Estimate the population mean with the sample averagemean(sample)#> [1] 10.03364# Draw a different sample and estimate again:sample <- rnorm(100,10,2)mean(sample)#> [1] 9.913197# Draw a third sample and estimate again:sample <- rnorm(100,10,2)mean(sample)#> [1] 10.21746 Ê®°Êì¨Êé®Ë´ñ # Set the random seedset.seed(123456)# initialize vectors to later store results:r <- 10000CIlower <- numeric(r); CIupper <- numeric(r)pvalue1 <- numeric(r); pvalue2 <- numeric(r)# repeat r times:for(j in 1:r) {# Draw a samplesample <- rnorm(100,10,2)# test the (correct) null hypothesis mu=10:testres1 <- t.test(sample,mu=10)# store CI & p value:CIlower[j] <- testres1$conf.int[1]CIupper[j] <- testres1$conf.int[2]pvalue1[j] <- testres1$p.value# test the (incorrect) null hypothesis mu=9.5 & store the p value:pvalue2[j] <- t.test(sample,mu=9.5)$p.value}# Test results as logical valuereject1<-pvalue1<=0.05; reject2<-pvalue2<=0.05table(reject1)#> reject1#> FALSE TRUE #> 9492 508table(reject2)#> reject2#> FALSE TRUE #> 3043 6957

title: mpg

ggplot ex  ÂèÉËÄÉ   library(ggplot2)ggplot(midwest, aes(x=area, y=poptotal)) + geom_point() ex library(ggplot2)ex1 <- ggplot(mtcars)ex1 <- ex1 + aes(x = mpg, y = wt)ex1 <- ex1 + geom_point()summary(ex1) #> data: mpg, cyl, disp, hp, drat, wt, qsec, vs, am, gear, carb [32x11]#> mapping: x = ~mpg, y = ~wt#> faceting: <ggproto object: Class FacetNull, Facet, gg>#> compute_layout: function#> draw_back: function#> draw_front: function#> draw_labels: function#> draw_panels: function#> finish_data: function#> init_scales: function#> map_data: function#> params: list#> setup_data: function#> setup_params: function#> shrink: TRUE#> train_scales: function#> vars: function#> super: <ggproto object: Class FacetNull, Facet, gg>#> -----------------------------------#> geom_point: na.rm = FALSE#> stat_identity: na.rm = FALSE#> position_identityex1 # üè∑ÈÄôË£°ÊâçÊúâÂúñÂá∫‰æÜ  ÈÉ®ÂàÜ‰øÆÊîπ: Âè™ÊîπËÆäÈ°èËâ≤
ex1 + geom_point(aes(colour = factor(cyl))) #üè∑Áî®Ê±ΩÁº∏ÂÄíÈ°èËâ≤  ÈÉ®ÂàÜ‰øÆÊîπ: Âè™ÊîπËÆäYËª∏
ex1 + geom_point(aes(y = disp)) Âà™Èô§
aes(y = NULL)#> Aesthetic mapping: #> * `y` -> NULLex1 mpg library(ggplot2)# First rows of data of data set mpg:head(mpg)#> # A tibble: 6 x 11#> manufacturer model displ year cyl trans drv cty hwy fl class #> <chr> <chr> <dbl> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 auto(l5) f 18 29 p compa~#> 2 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 manual(m5) f 21 29 p compa~#> 3 audi a4 2 2008 4 manual(m6) f 20 31 p compa~#> 4 audi a4 2 2008 4 auto(av) f 21 30 p compa~#> 5 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 auto(l5) f 16 26 p compa~#> 6 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 manual(m5) f 18 26 p compa~ggplot() + geom_point( data=mpg, mapping=aes(x=displ, y=hwy) )ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy)) + geom_point() +geom_smooth()#> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula 'y ~ x' ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy)) + geom_point(color=gray(0.5)) +geom_smooth(color="black")#> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula 'y ~ x' ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy)) + geom_point( aes(color=class) ) +geom_smooth(color="black") +scale_color_grey() +scale_shape_manual(values=1:7)#> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula 'y ~ x' ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy, color=class, shape=class)) title: ÂâçÁΩÆÊ∫ñÂÇô
content:
install.packages("wooldridge")install.packages("rio")# moreinstall.packages("WDI")install.packages("dplyr")install.packages("ggplot") Á∑¥ÁøíË≥áÊñôÁöÑÂπæÁ®ÆËºâÂÖ•Ë≥áÊñôÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ï
data(affairs, package='wooldridge')# Version 2: Adjust pathaffairs2 <- rio::import("~/data/wooldridge/affairs.dta")# Version 3: Change working directorysetwd("~/data/wooldridge")affairs3 <- rio::import("affairs.dta")# Version 4: directly load from internetaffairs4 <- rio::import("http://fmwww.bc.edu/ec-p/data/wooldridge/affairs.dta") ‰ª•Â•ó‰ª∂ËºâÂÖ•ÁÇ∫‰æã
data(affairs, package='wooldridge')# Ë®àÁÆóÂπ≥Âùámean(affairs$naffairs)#> [1] 1.455907 ‰∏ÄËà¨Ë≥áÊñôËôïÁêÜ - ËÆÄ„ÄÅËΩâ„ÄÅÁÆó„ÄÅÂØ´ # Define one x vector for all:year <- c(2008,2009,2010,2011,2012,2013)# Define a matrix of y values:product1<-c(0,3,6,9,7,8); product2<-c(1,2,3,5,9,6); product3<-c(2,4,4,2,3,2)sales_mat <- cbind(product1,product2,product3)rownames(sales_mat) <- year# The matrix looks like this:sales_mat#> product1 product2 product3#> 2008 0 1 2#> 2009 3 2 4#> 2010 6 3 4#> 2011 9 5 2#> 2012 7 9 3#> 2013 8 6 2# Create a data frame and display it:sales <- as.data.frame(sales_mat)sales#> product1 product2 product3#> 2008 0 1 2#> 2009 3 2 4#> 2010 6 3 4#> 2011 9 5 2#> 2012 7 9 3#> 2013 8 6 2# save data frame as RData file (in the current working directory)save(sales, file = "oursalesdata.RData")# remove data frame "sales" from memoryrm(sales)# Does variable "sales" exist?exists("sales")#> [1] FALSE# Load data set (in the current working directory):load("oursalesdata.RData")# Does variable "sales" exist?exists("sales")#> [1] TRUEsales#> product1 product2 product3#> 2008 0 1 2#> 2009 3 2 4#> 2010 6 3 4#> 2011 9 5 2#> 2012 7 9 3#> 2013 8 6 2# averages of the variables:colMeans(sales)#> product1 product2 product3 #> 5.500000 4.333333 2.833333 basic statistic 1 - pnorm(2,4,3) + pnorm(-2,4,3)#> [1] 0.7702576# Using the transformation:pnorm(2/3) - pnorm(-2/3)#> [1] 0.4950149# Working directly with the distribution of X:pnorm(6,4,3) - pnorm(2,4,3)#> [1] 0.4950149 table # load data setdata(affairs, package='wooldridge')# Generate "Factors" to attach labelshaskids <- factor(affairs$kids,labels=c("no","yes"))mlab <- c("very unhappy","unhappy","average","happy", "very happy")marriage <- factor(affairs$ratemarr, labels=mlab)# Frequencies for having kids:table(haskids)#> haskids#> no yes #> 171 430# Marriage ratings (share):prop.table(table(marriage))#> marriage#> very unhappy unhappy average happy very happy #> 0.0266223 0.1098170 0.1547421 0.3227953 0.3860233# Contigency table: counts (display & store in var.)(countstab <- table(marriage,haskids))#> haskids#> marriage no yes#> very unhappy 3 13#> unhappy 8 58#> average 24 69#> happy 40 154#> very happy 96 136# Share within "marriage" (i.e. within a row):prop.table(countstab, margin=1)#> haskids#> marriage no yes#> very unhappy 0.1875000 0.8125000#> unhappy 0.1212121 0.8787879#> average 0.2580645 0.7419355#> happy 0.2061856 0.7938144#> very happy 0.4137931 0.5862069# Share within "haskids" (i.e. within a column):prop.table(countstab, margin=2)#> haskids#> marriage no yes#> very unhappy 0.01754386 0.03023256#> unhappy 0.04678363 0.13488372#> average 0.14035088 0.16046512#> happy 0.23391813 0.35813953#> very happy 0.56140351 0.31627907 data frame # Define one x vector for all:year <- c(2008,2009,2010,2011,2012,2013)# Define a matrix of y values:product1<-c(0,3,6,9,7,8); product2<-c(1,2,3,5,9,6); product3<-c(2,4,4,2,3,2)sales_mat <- cbind(product1,product2,product3)rownames(sales_mat) <- year# The matrix looks like this:sales_mat#> product1 product2 product3#> 2008 0 1 2#> 2009 3 2 4#> 2010 6 3 4#> 2011 9 5 2#> 2012 7 9 3#> 2013 8 6 2# Create a data frame and display it:sales <- as.data.frame(sales_mat)sales#> product1 product2 product3#> 2008 0 1 2#> 2009 3 2 4#> 2010 6 3 4#> 2011 9 5 2#> 2012 7 9 3#> 2013 8 6 2 Á∑¥Áøí Wdi library(WDI)wdi_raw <- WDI(indicator=c("SP.DYN.LE00.FE.IN"),start = 1960, end = 2014) # üè∑WDI ÊòØ‰∏ÄÂÄãÂáΩÊï∏,wdi_rawÊòØ‰∏ÄÂÄãdata.frame # ‰∏çË¶ÅÁõ¥Êé•È°ØÁ§∫ÊâÄÊúâË≥áÊñô,Â§™Èï∑head(wdi_raw,n=10)#> iso2c country SP.DYN.LE00.FE.IN year#> 1 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 63.74479 2014#> 2 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 63.01116 2013#> 3 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 62.19697 2012#> 4 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 61.31294 2011#> 5 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 60.37721 2010#> 6 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 59.40726 2009#> 7 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 58.42882 2008#> 8 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 57.47517 2007#> 9 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 56.57331 2006#> 10 ZH Africa Eastern and Southern 55.75485 2005#tail(wdi_raw) descriptive statistics data(ceosal1, package='wooldridge') # class(ceosal1) = data.frame# sample average:mean(ceosal1$salary)#> [1] 1281.12# sample median:median(ceosal1$salary)#> [1] 1039#standard deviation:sd(ceosal1$salary)#> [1] 1372.345# summary information:summary(ceosal1$salary)#> Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Max. #> 223 736 1039 1281 1407 14822# correlation with ROE:cor(ceosal1$salary, ceosal1$roe)#> [1] 0.1148417 tÊ™¢ÂÆö # data for the scrap rates examples:SR87<-c(10,1,6,.45,1.25,1.3,1.06,3,8.18,1.67,.98,1,.45,5.03,8,9,18,.28, 7,3.97)SR88<-c(3,1,5,.5,1.54,1.5,.8,2,.67,1.17,.51,.5,.61,6.7,4,7,19,.2,5,3.83)Change <- SR88 - SR87# Ingredients to CI formula(avgCh<- mean(Change)) # ChangeÁöÑÂπ≥Âùá#> [1] -1.1545(n <- length(Change))#> [1] 20(sdCh <- sd(Change)) # ChangeÁöÑÊ®ôÊ∫ñÂ∑Æ#> [1] 2.400639(se <- sdCh/sqrt(n)) # Ê®ôÊ∫ñË™§#> [1] 0.5367992(c <- qt(.975, n-1)) #quantile of t dist#> [1] 2.093024# avgChÁöÑ95%‰ø°Ë≥¥ÂçÄÈñìc( avgCh - c*se, avgCh + c*se )#> [1] -2.27803369 -0.03096631# t statistic for H0: mu=0:(t <- avgCh/se)#> [1] -2.150711# p value(p <- pt(t,n-1)) # üè∑p(probabilityÊ©üÁéá) ‚ûï tÂàÜÈÖç = pt #> [1] 0.02229063 ÊàñÊòØÁõ¥Êé•‰ΩøÁî®ÂáΩÊï∏,Â∞çÁÖßÂ¶Ç‰∏ã
# two-sided CIt.test(Change)#> #> One Sample t-test#> #> data: Change#> t = -2.1507, df = 19, p-value = 0.04458#> alternative hypothesis: true mean is not equal to 0#> 95 percent confidence interval:#> -2.27803369 -0.03096631#> sample estimates:#> mean of x #> -1.1545# 1-sided test:t.test(Change, alternative="less")#> #> One Sample t-test#> #> data: Change#> t = -2.1507, df = 19, p-value = 0.02229#> alternative hypothesis: true mean is less than 0#> 95 percent confidence interval:#> -Inf -0.2263028#> sample estimates:#> mean of x #> -1.1545 Á∑¥ÁøíÁØÑ‰æã data(audit, package='wooldridge')# two-sided CIt.test(audit$y)# 1-sided test:t.test(audit$y, alternative="less") ‰ø°Ë≥¥ÂçÄÈñì data(audit, package='wooldridge')# Ingredients to CI formula(avgy<- mean(audit$y))#> [1] -0.1327801(n <- length(audit$y))#> [1] 241(sdy <- sd(audit$y))#> [1] 0.4819709(se <- sdy/sqrt(n))#> [1] 0.03104648(c <- qnorm(.975)) # üè∑q ‚ûï Â∏∏ÊÖã(norm) = qnorm #> [1] 1.959964# 95% Confidence intervall:avgy + c * c(-se,+se)#> [1] -0.19363006 -0.07193011# 99% Confidence intervall:avgy + qnorm(.995) * c(-se,+se)#> [1] -0.21275051 -0.05280966 # t statistic for H0: mu=0:(t <- avgy/se) #-4.276816 #> [1] -4.276816# p value(p <- pt(t,240))#> [1] 1.369271e-05# Critical values for t distribution with n-1=240 d.f.:alpha.one.tailed = c(0.1, 0.05, 0.025, 0.01, 0.005, .001)CV <- qt(1 - alpha.one.tailed, n-1) # üè∑q ‚ûï tÂàÜÈÖç = qt cbind(alpha.one.tailed, CV)#> alpha.one.tailed CV#> [1,] 0.100 1.285089#> [2,] 0.050 1.651227#> [3,] 0.025 1.969898#> [4,] 0.010 2.341985#> [5,] 0.005 2.596469#> [6,] 0.001 3.124536 plot basic plot curve(dnorm(x,0,1),-10,10,lwd=1,lty=1)curve(dnorm(x,0,2),-10,10,add=TRUE,lwd=1,lty=1) #üè∑ÁñäÂúñ curve(dnorm(x,0,3),-10,10,add=TRUE,lwd=1,lty=1) histogram data(ceosal1, package='wooldridge')# Extract ROE to single vectorROE <- ceosal1$roe# Subfigure (a): histogram (counts)hist(ROE)# Subfigure (b): histogram (densities, explicit breaks)hist(ROE, breaks=c(0,5,10,20,30,60) ) ggplot2 library(ggplot2)head(mpg)#> # A tibble: 6 x 11#> manufacturer model displ year cyl trans drv cty hwy fl class #> <chr> <chr> <dbl> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> #> 1 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 auto(l5) f 18 29 p compa~#> 2 audi a4 1.8 1999 4 manual(m5) f 21 29 p compa~#> 3 audi a4 2 2008 4 manual(m6) f 20 31 p compa~#> 4 audi a4 2 2008 4 auto(av) f 21 30 p compa~#> 5 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 auto(l5) f 16 26 p compa~#> 6 audi a4 2.8 1999 6 manual(m5) f 18 26 p compa~ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy)) + geom_point() +geom_smooth()#> `geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula 'y ~ x'

N<-10metasample<-rnorm(N,5,2)bmu<-numeric(1000)for(i in 1:1000){rndno<-as.integer(runif(N)*N)+1 smp<-metasample[rndno]bmu[i]<-mean(smp)}p<-density(bmu)plot(p)qq<-quantile(bmu)rug(qq,col="red")qq#> 0% 25% 50% 75% 100% #> 3.810875 5.332504 5.745269 6.147151 7.410791 N<-100metasample<-rnorm(N,5,2)bmu<-numeric(1000)for(i in 1:1000){rndno<-as.integer(runif(N)*N)+1 smp<-metasample[rndno]bmu[i]<-mean(smp)}p<-density(bmu)plot(p)qq<-quantile(bmu)rug(qq,col="red")qq#> 0% 25% 50% 75% 100% #> 4.129242 4.771216 4.906050 5.033250 5.510479 N<-100metasample<-rnorm(N,5,2)hinfo<-hist(metasample)lx<-seq(min(metasample),max(metasample),length=100)ly<-dnorm(lx,mean(metasample),sd(metasample))sy<-ly*(diff(lx)[1])*N lines(lx,sy,col="blue") N<-100metasample<-rnorm(N,5,2)hinfo<-hist(metasample)ly<-dnorm(hinfo$mids,mean(metasample),sd(metasample))sy<-ly*(diff(hinfo$mids)[1])*N lines(hinfo$mids,sy,col="blue")
